positive.review:
I have never played a deck builder with any real dedication before and for whatever reason this one has kept my attention. 

First. The mushrooms are the best, a machine that springs to life with enough ease that even a consummate 'can't see the forest for the trees person' (me) is able to yield positive results. 

Second. Gilda is the worst. 

Third, the writing in this game, the little scenes where we get asides with the characters are charmingly bad but they're so sincere that I'm pleased each time I get a small interior shot of the internal drama of the various factions. 

The art in this game can be a bit all over the place but by god if they're depicting a little guy they're going to nail it. 

I think probably after 300 hours of game play I should have something to say about the systems or the tactics or the deck building but again, I've played one deck builder so I feel like my opinion is just too shallow for it to be worth while and probably not what a person who is interested in deckbuilders is looking for. 

That said, the daily challenges are the best part of this game compared with the 'standard runs' you can customise for yourself. They have a 'boutique' customised vibe to them that the pure randomness of the standard runs lack.

Anyway, thank you to the creators.

P.s. please buff Gilda, she has so much room for potential.

Monster Train 2 is a worthy sequel that expands the original’s deckbuilding roguelike formula with fresh ideas. 

The game keeps its signature mix of card strategy and tower-defense combat, set on a train climbing toward a corrupted Heaven. 

Five new clans bring unique mechanics, offering plenty of replayability and creative deck synergies.
Visually, it’s polished and vibrant, while the gameplay remains fast-paced and addictive.

For me it is better than MT1 and I recommend it to everyone.

Absolutely loved the multiplayer mode from the first game and was a bit disappointed to hear it was cut from this game due to low player count. With proper lobby support and even daily mutators it would be a hit!

Was worried how the sequel was going to match and exceed the first, and by god did you manage it. Highly reccomend if you, like me, love deck builder card battlers.

Monster Train 2 is a strategic roguelike deck building game with a twist. Set on a train to hell, you’ll choose from multiple tracks to send your train down, with different potential Roguelite benefits in each location. Ranging from Unit Buffs, Spell Buffs, New Cards, Equipment, and random events that may allow you to create broken combos.

Monster Train 2 is an improvement on Monster Train 1, I had a total of 204.7 hours on Monster Train1, I currently have 358.7 hours played with Monster Train 2. The game isn't the same but is the same, it's hard to explain.

The difficulty settings I believe transition better as compared to Monster Train 1.
The units feel a bit more balanced. You'll still come across builds that overall are better than others. And honestly sometimes I believe a few things need to be balanced differently. 

There are some unique challenge levels that give you some in game cosmetics. Thees challenges are more like puzzles, where you have to figure out what way can you win with what you are provided or not provided. 

There are more clans, more combos to come up with, more challenges, and some funny little stories added into the game. The little easter eggs here and there are fun. 

A must buy DeckBuilder.

Monster Train 2 is not only the best card battler /deckbuilder of 2025, it's also one of the best games of 2025 and a top tier card battler along with its predecessor, Slay the Spire and Beneath Oresa. This game only needed to bring back all the things that were good about the first one and maybe touch up a few things to keep the experience fresh... It did a heck of a lot more than that. There are FIVE new factions as of this moment in addition to five of the six factions we already had in the first game. 

Monster Train 2, like its predecessor, is a roguelite card battler in which you embark upon runs. Each run has a series of combat encounters, and after each combat encounter you arrive to a resting area where you can upgrade and modify your deck in various ways. Combat encounters take place in a train of sorts. There are four floors, enemies enter the bottom floor and try to make their way to the fourth floor where your pyre is to destroy it. And it is, of course, up to you to stop them. When your pyre’s health reaches zero, it’s game over. 

In Monster Train 2 there are factions… and this time you have all the original factions you had in Monster Train… and no less than five new factions. Each of these factions has a broad array of unique creatures and spells that have the potential to work in beautiful tandem depending on your strategy. You choose two factions at the beginning of the run: a primary faction and a support faction, and the best news is that every faction has an insane number of cross-class synergies that make one plus one equal five. And this translates into a deliciously rewarding tactical experience. 

Shiny Shoe don’t seem to be running out of ideas, quite the contrary. Some of the new factions are even better than the ones we already had  were pretty awesome. 

In the original Monster Train you had Spells and Creatures as your primary card types. Monster train introduces the Equipment card type. This card type is comparable to enchantments in Magic The Gathering. You have creature equipment cards and room equipment cards. 

Creature equipment cards need to be attached to a creature during an encounter, and they last until the creature dies. These cards add all sorts of new effects and skills. And there are many other components in the game that synergize really well with equipment cards. There are effects that trigger every time an equipment card is used, for example. There is also the Graft skill which many creatures from the Lazarus faction have. These creatures come with a built-in piece of equipment and when they die, said equipment returns to your hand and you get the chance to use it again on some other creatures. In fact, equipment-based builds are very much a thing with the Lazarus faction. 

Then you have Room Equipment cards. These cards are applied to an entire floor and they have effects that affect allied or enemy creatures every time their conditions are met.  

Creature cards already had a bunch of skills in the original Monster Train and now there are many more, and they aren’t just there to bloat the gameplay meaninglessly, they have tactical value, they can be used as the turn-stone of your deck’s build and they can work in beautiful synergy with other skills. It’s in-freaking-sane, no other card battler comes close to this. Some creature cards now have skills that can be triggered by the player after he or she has summoned them, Magic the Gathering style. And I always thought the original game needed something like this, skills that you could activate and use on allied or enemy units. 

In the first Monster Train you could boost your creatures with shield, armor, spikes, regenerate and lifestel amongst other things, and now you have new ways to boost them like various retaliatory effects. 

Spell cards also go way beyond your typical damage and boosting effects. You can pull enemies to the front or push them to the back, you can root them so that they don’t move to the next floor or, daze them so that they lose their turn or weaken them so that they don’t do damage or force them to an upper or lower floor. There are spells that serve to accelerate certain mechanics or trigger certain conditions. And they are all also very tactical. You already had the Stygian faction in Monster Train, which relied very heavily on magic. Now you also have the Luna Coven, which is also very magic focused but uses a completely different approach.

After every combat encounter you reach a resting area, in which you can upgrade your cards, restore your pyre’s health or try your luck with a random event. There are two mutually exclusive paths that you can follow and it’s always a good idea to look at the upcoming resting areas and their facilities to plan your journey more efficiently. Cards don’t have fixed upgrades like they do in some card battlers or a choice of two like they do in some others. Not that there’s anything wrong with that, but Monster Train 2, just does it better. 

Upgrades are purchasable items that you can attach to your cards. And you have two upgrade slots by default. Creatures with the “sweep" skill damage all enemies every time they attack. So if you give them the upgrade that makes them quick and adds 10 damage to their attack, you can wipe out an entire floor of enemies before they even know what’s going on. It’s crazy fun and the possibilities are endless.

So your goal is to prevent your pyre from dying, but in the original monster train your pyre could only attack. In monster train two you can unlock different pyres with different abilities and tradeoffs. There is a pyre, for example, that has an ability that you can trigger once per encounter that gives you plus three energy.

Now you have a new game mode: the dimensional portal. And it’s actually pretty freaking fun. This is a mod in which you have a series of unlockable pre-designed challenges. You don’t get to choose your factions or your pyre and you usually get an insanely powerful modifier and one that’s equally punishing. This a mod that you have to unlock, so by the time you get to sink your teeth into it, you are already going be more than familiar with the game’s mechanics. And this is a good thing. Because this mod is about using your knowledge of the game’s mechanics and the mechanics of each faction to solve an additional problem that gets thrown at you.

So new factions with new cards and synergies, new card types, new skills and new pyres... this is all crazy good especially if you consider that they are not there to bloat the experience but to make the game replayable in meaningful ways. And a new alternative game mod that makes the game more about tactical puzzle solving than about deck building. What's not to like about this bad boy???

Monster Train 1 was a top-tier entry into the Spire-a-like subgenre from the moment it dropped, and Monster Train 2 improves upon it in almost every way! Continuing the musically excellent, artistically beautiful and altogether cohesive backdrops upon which Shiny Shoe craft their roguelite deckbuilders, this game feels like it refines the IP's innovative 3-tier approach to combat, comments on the blossoming potential left in the wake of other giants in the genre, and undoubtedly also cements itself among them.

Do I recommend? Yes. but not without some reservations. There is alot of play time to be had in this game and it the basic game play structure is decent. But when it gets down to the nitty gritty this game is a painful, grinding time sink. You will have to keep repeating the same play through hoping to unlock something better to get further in. It`s slow going and very repetitive. Also very luck related. Wish it could have offered more choices and paths so that victory felt like it was based on your strategic brilliance rather than luck.

When Wendy's released the Baconator, they asked the question "What's better than a bacon cheeseburger?" and answered it with "TWO bacon cheeseburgers stacked on top of each other." Monster Train 2 is the Baconator of rogue-like deck builders. They took everything that was great about the first game and just piled on more: more factions, more cards, more enemies, more relics, etc. If you liked Monster Train 1, Slay the Spire, or any of the many other games in this genre, you will easily be foundered by this game.

Have been fortunate enough to be an official playtester for this absolute gem of a game, the amount of blood sweat and tears the devs poured (and still keep pouring) into this game to make it the best it can be is absolutely amazing.

If you were a fan of the first Monster Train, you'll be right at home with this one. It's a lot of the same formula, and a fair bit more. Quality of life improvements go over well, and it breathes some new life into some of the original content, at that. As far as completing runs, you'll probably find it easier than Slay the Spire, but this is moot, considering you could argue most runs in either game can become trivial if you find a good game plan. 

While this seems a bit extra to add, if these sorts of things matter to you, it might be worth considering. 

I was a little hesitant to purchase instantly, considering the vibes I got toward how the first game was handled initially. It felt like the content hit a brick wall and gave the feeling that it was abandonware at a point, as they were all-in on their next venture, Inkbound. This game, sadly, had been shaping up to be a DLC and cosmetic-addled mess, despite the gameplay being decent. 

I WILL give them credit for responding to the near instantaneous backlash. They backpedalled on that format and removed the leveling and season pass stuff pretty quick. While they did not give refunds to anyone who spent money, they did give them double the currency or more to unlock things, or instantly unlocked everything that would be in "Supporter packs" that you can buy that served more as expansions. I've seen these things handled a lot more poorly before. That said, that game is now sort of in that "abandonware" state, now that they're focused on Monster Train 2. I'm not thoroughly convinced Monster Train 2 won't hit that kind of vibe eventually if they get another venture going.

HOWEVER, their games are still fun, and complete packages (though there are more bugs in Inkbound that are a bit iffy.) A developer isn't beholden to their games forever, no matter how good they are, and it's absolutely a reasonable way of handling stuff, thus, I am still giving this game a positive review. 

If you prefer living games that just keep on giving though, there's plenty of other options out there. You're still going to get your value out of buying this game, even when it's not on sale.

If you liked the first Monster Train (MT1), this is a no-brainer. It adds new gameplay and QoL systems that really enrich the experience. My favourite new QoL feature is the ability to reset your turn (no penalties, no limits) or the battle (you cannot change your trial decision though). I've managed to scrape through battles I thought were unwinnable thanks to that feature, and it felt so satisfying!

If you like deck builders in general but have not played MT1 before, I highly recommend this game (I really enjoyed Slay the Spire too). There's no real need to get MT1 either because this game supersedes its predecessor in every way.

In fact (spoilers for those who played MT1), [spoiler]at a certain point of progression in the game, you'll unlock ALL the base game clans from the first game (the DLC clan from MT1 excluded)[/spoiler]

Overall, what I enjoy most about this game is how it does not shy away from letting you build decks that feel so broken in the best synergistic ways. If you like that feeling too you'll probably enjoy this game!

Shiny Shoe Took a 9.5/10 game, made a sequel, and builded like they were out to ensure no one played another strategy deckbuilder game for years to come. You are tired and on the edge of your seat from the very first round? You've a deployment mode now. You feel  Quick + Sweep is OP, they introduce Corruption, and have you face 3 Bosses in the end, and an Endless mode to boot! So many Strategies that you just cant yelling "Strats on Strats on Strats on Strats!" as you employ Equipment, Room Cards, better Artifacts and everything else in between. 

The only thing I miss from MT1 (initially their art but no longer) the flavortext of the cards! I'm glad they focused on writing and some conversation cutscenes, but I miss dense and cryptic flavortext on cards from before!

My one issue is that some enemy mechanics swing a little too far in one direction. A few fights feel too easy and others feel annoying in a way that does not add much strategy. It is not enough to ruin the game, but it does stand out when most of the design feels tight.

Overall, Monster Train 2 is a very addictive game with a ton of variety. If you enjoy making broken combos or trying out new deck ideas, there is a lot to like here. I had a great time with it and I am excited to keep discovering new builds.
Just out right improves upon the first game. Lots of fun and lots of combinations to keep you entertained.

If you enjoyed the first Monster Train, this is just a better version of it with more content. 
Monster Train 2 is one of the best games in the roguelike deckbuilder genre

Realistically, this game is my GOTY. 
I was crazy about Monster Train, my absolute favorite deck building roguelike, and they improved upon the first game in every single way with this. I can only DREAM that they would bless me with a third in the distant future. Even when I put it down for a while I always always always come back. I love the themes, I love the art, I love the music, I love the game feel, the mechanics, design ethos. Its the game I have the most fun while losing in my entire library. And when I WIN? The dopamine hit is insane. I immediately want to play again. I am motivated more in this game than any other game I own to try and 100% it. I am nearing 30 out of 180 combos beaten and while its extremely daunting I am just so delighted to put that effort in, which is extremely out of character for me. Can't recommend it enough, and I hope the devs know they knocked this shit out of the park and I love them to death for it. 
My parting words: As long as it isn't a buggy mess I will buy any and all paid DLC you put out for this game and I beg and plead on my knees for it. <3

Fun but difficult.

negative.review:
Comparing this to Monster Train 1
>Game is lacking most of the challenge/difficulty options, so it's much easier
>Base system changes make the gameplay much less interesting mechanically
>Enemy abilities prevent all but the most braindead strategy from working and you can't see which enemies you will get, so you always have to play exactly the same way. The game is incredibly easy (I've got a 65 winstreak on the highest difficulty and have won this game on the hardest setting with every clan combination, as you can see in my screenshots), but you're forced to do the same thing every time because e.g. floor silence or sweep enemies completely shut down any alternative ways of playing.
>Horrible forced in indie references in the events
>Events are so overpowered that if you draw one you just win instantly. Getting Dante basically just ends the run in a win.
>Animations are slow even on the highest setting
>Sound is still an issue because of the noise some enemies make when getting hit, especially since multiattack is so inflated compared to MT1
>Terrible redditcore writing in forced story cutscenes where MT1 just had cool MtG style worldbuilding on card flavor

In general, it's an inferior product in every respect. There is no circumstance where you should buy this if you don't own MT1. Only if you've 100%'d MT1 and want more even if it is a downgrade should you consider this game.

I somehow cannot understand the positive reviews. It is more content on the first look but somehow the new enemy mechanics like resurrection etc demand a more specific gameplay style from you. I so often had runs which went smoothly just to be totally crushed by a certain type of enemy.

Monster Train 1 also feels more polished, I think it is the better choice. Besides also having better writing and graphics.
You can't reset fights by going to the main menu any more. That was my favorite part about the original game. A misplay/mis-input can brick your run. Ruins the experience as a second monitor game.

The sequel has the exact same problems as the first game that make it only adequate as a roguleike deckbuilder. It fails to provide meaningful upgrades to the player to help reduce variance like the GOATS of this category do, like Slay the Spire.

I just don't feel that it's an improvement over the first game.
Initially I was super excited for "more monster train", but after having played it (and possibly because I played the first one sooo much) this release didn't strike that same excitement I was expecting.
It's not bad, but I'd definitely recommend the MT1 first.

It's moostly fun but it's a little too player-hostile I think. Winning a run on covenant 10 so far really feels like "get lucky with the exact right amount of greed and power given to you at the start of the run and also already know exactly what the upcoming bosses will be and if you want to do the superboss you also have to get some overpowered crap from an event as opposed to most of the events which do basically nothing. Lots of the things that are obvious holdovers from the first game are absolutely useless. Something like half the relics are almost useless (scorched steel...) and certain others are better than boss relics... I love how this game looks, I love how it sounds, I even mostly liked the story, but slamming my head against the wall until the wall decides to be suddenly softer this time to get a covenant 10 win is crazy. The scaling about...halfway up, is fine, but at like...8 or so, the game REALLY stops having ANY wiggle room for not conforming to exactly what you should have built. Maybe nerf some things and give the option to revert it in steps throughout the run for a score bonus or as part of a cov11? but as it stands now it's a little too much. Also most bosses that get stronger when they climb floors (most of them) have effects that are so insanely overtuned that if you do not defeat them on the bottom floor you lose with no option to recover. Similar for the 2 new bosses, which are otherwise exemplars of the visual and audio treat that this game otherwise is! Get some balance fixes for both player stuff and enemies, and tweak down the difficulty SLIGHTLY at least post cov-8 or so and this game is a treat. As it stands right now...eeeeeeeh?
It's shiny and gives an impression of depth but I don't find many of my decisions very interesting.

This game plays like an idle game for the first 30-50 minutes of a run to build up into nothing spectacular or interesting. Huge downgrade from the first.

Just... doesn't click like the prequel did.

It's the same core game mechanics, just with new types of cards (room/equips) and new sets of cards and enemies. But somehow it feels less engaging than Monster Train 1. There's a boatload more of interactions and effects (or so it feels at least) that make clear and concise planning difficult. Also, it ups the overall power level, together with aforementioned new card types adding new layers of synergy... which very quickly leads to a boom or bust gameplay where either you get those 3-5 cards that create a great synergy that fullclears bosses on the first floor without taking damage, or you don't and you just die to attrition as every boss makes their way into your pyre floor. I've not yet ever felt like there was a situation in between those extremes: that would be, a tight fight where careful planning and execution of your hand just barely nets you a victory. It's always either an auto win or an auto loss, solely dependent on whether you get (and then pick) the right cards and upgrades.

Furthermore, the clan theming just feels... not as consistent as the previous ones. In Monster Train 1, you had the fiery zerk demons, the magefish, the green defense plant deck, the suicidally fanatic candles, etc... in Monster Train 2 you have... a wild mix of blue angels with a semi-conditional two-stat affecting buff spiel and a metric ton of movement spells that don't really synergize well, a wild mix of dragons that throw about greed and fire (I'll say, this is the only clan that actually felt consistent), a moon faction that mixes a supposed focus on spellcasting with random assassins and an overarching mechanic of making sure to draft that one card that will allow you to freely obsolete their entire 'moon phase' mechanic, fungi/uy that spam debuffs and a weird stack-unit spawn that is weirdly implemented as it is brokenly powerful and a frankenstein faction that goes all in on RNGing your way to victory withotu having a clear theme or kit beyond that.
It just doesn't feel right.

And then there's the balance. No offense, but if you present a sufficiently complex deckbuilder like this, and your first run takes you straight to the final boss, something is off. And it gets worse when you then have some factions that will absolutely trivialize the game from fight 1 to 8, whilst others will be utterly dependent on RNGing the right drafts at start to even make it past fight 2. This becomes particularly visible when you pick up a newly unlocked faction for a first run on your highest covenant level (aka difficulty), trivially beat it, but then go back to one of the previous factions and repeatedly struggle through runs trying to do the same.

Oh, and you also get a light set of occasional story dialogue blurps that are forgettably generic dialogue to throw exposition at you, because apparently card-based roguelikes rely on their story to motivate players?

In Monster Train 1, you had the fiery zerk demons, the magefish, the green defense plant deck, the suicidally fanatic candles, etc... in Monster Train 2 you have... a wild mix of blue angels with a semi-conditional two-stat affecting buff spiel and a metric ton of movement spells that don't really synergize well, a wild mix of dragons that throw about greed and fire (I'll say, this is the only clan that actually felt consistent), a moon faction that mixes a supposed focus on spellcasting with random assassins and an overarching mechanic of making sure to draft that one card that will allow you to freely obsolete their entire 'moon phase' mechanic, fungi/uy that spam debuffs and a weird stack-unit spawn that is weirdly implemented as it is brokenly powerful and a frankenstein faction that goes all in on RNGing your way to victory withotu having a clear theme or kit beyond that.
It just doesn't feel right.

And then there's the balance. No offense, but if you present a sufficiently complex deckbuilder like this, and your first run takes you straight to the final boss, something is off. And it gets worse when you then have some factions that will absolutely trivialize the game from fight 1 to 8, whilst others will be utterly dependent on RNGing the right drafts at start to even make it past fight 2. This becomes particularly visible when you pick up a newly unlocked faction for a first run on your highest covenant level (aka difficulty), trivially beat it, but then go back to one of the previous factions and repeatedly struggle through runs trying to do the same.

Oh, and you also get a light set of occasional story dialogue blurps that are forgettably generic dialogue to throw exposition at you, because apparently card-based roguelikes rely on their story to motivate players? 


Overall score: 4/10
It's not all bad, but I just don't see a reason to play this over any other contender in an arguably oversaturated genre, including it's predecessor.

Lots of the things that are obvious holdovers from the first game are absolutely useless. Something like half the relics are almost useless (scorched steel...) and certain others are better than boss relics... I love how this game looks, I love how it sounds, I even mostly liked the story, but slamming my head against the wall until the wall decides to be suddenly softer this time to get a covenant 10 win is crazy. The scaling about...halfway up, is fine, but at like...8 or so, the game REALLY stops having ANY wiggle room for not conforming to exactly what you should have built. Maybe nerf some things and give the option to revert it in steps throughout the run for a score bonus or as part of a cov11? but as it stands now it's a little too much. Also most bosses that get stronger when they climb floors (most of them) have effects that are so insanely overtuned that if you do not defeat them on the bottom floor you lose with no option to recover. Similar for the 2 new bosses, which are otherwise exemplars of the visual and audio treat that this game otherwise is! Get some balance fixes for both player stuff and enemies, and tweak down the difficulty SLIGHTLY at least post cov-8 or so and this game is a treat. As it stands right now...eeeeeeeh?
